Years ago I found out that Jumping spiders are predatory to other spiders.  We don’t kill jumping spiders, we name them and let them wander around the house. They have a super sticky (usually dirty too) and strong hunting web that they will occupy for only part of the day. This is the first video I've seen you do that is almost completely misinformed. I hope you find the following comments helpful. The characters you use to identify brown recluse are misleading (i.e., no comparison with similarly-colored, co-occurring filistatids and phoclids); your statement about them biting only 50% of people with which they come in contact is preposterous, even though your overall message that they are not aggressive is accurate (you may be thinking about aggression studies on black widows, which showed much less than 50% biting frequency, but as far as I know these studies have not even been conducted for brown recluse); the bit about them "hiding in bedsheets" and "getting them out  of the closet" only to be bitten shortly after is misleading since clearly millions of people live with huge populations of these spiders and receive no bites (i.e., no need for fear-mongering rhetoric); perhaps most importantly, the connection between brown recluse bites and most of those huge necrotic lesions found with google searches is essentially internet hype (most of those lesions are thought to be caused by other factors such as flesh-eating bacteria). Should brown recluse venom be respected? Absolutely. Recluse spiders have powerful venom that can produce painful reactions. But there is no need to perpetuate the misinformed hype about the species. Better to do as you have done with so many of your other videos to protect your daughter against misinformation: seek well-supported evidence for claims. Finally, I'm no PETA supporter... but yea... that's a messed up way to handle a spider. Countless others are photographing much more dangerous species with lesser equipment. There is just no reason to mockingly post the demise of an organism to the internet in the guise of education. I hope you feel ashamed for doing so. And I say all of this with the full intention of continuing to watch your videos. Love your work, excepting the present work.

There are more spiders in this world than there are 5x the amount of humans currently inhabiting the planet. If you're upset over one being killed out of defense a mans daughter or anyone else  is harmed then you are the epitome of an uneducated cry baby. Spiders have no concept of themselves, their children, or other creatures for that matter. They live to reproduce. Some spiders even need special hormones to stay dormant after their eggs hatch so that they don't become aggressive enough to kill and eat their own flesh and blood. They become so dormant that other spiders or animals can literally walk on them, invade their territory, even attack them without being harmed by said spider. It's the nature of them. So get off your "I love all animals" high horse and start realizing the world is dangerous and will eat you up and spit you out if you have any sympathy for undomesticated creatures.

They are completely harmless to you or your kids, but they are incredible predators of other spiders and various pests despite looking tiny and frail. I found one in my apartment and relocated it near the hinges of my front door. It stayed, and I have been sweeping away exoskeleton debris of wannabe intruders under its web ever since. I haven't found a single brown recluse in my apartment since enlisting the assistance of my security measure. The only spider I've found in my place recently was another cellar spider, which I put on a broom and moved outside.

First off, hi i love your videos, and i live around the city of Baltimore, MD. I got bit by a brown recluse spider and the funny thing is, oh and let me just put it out there that i have a number of health problems, and my body doesn't do a lot of things right. At least it seems like it doesn't. Im curious if anyone else has had this result. Okay drs say it was definitely a brown recluse that bit me. Well, i didn't get that rotten skin thing. Instead, i got a major case of a STAPH/MRSA the size of a ping pong ball. It was disgusting Haha. Oozing and bleeding and ugh. It was bad. I actually had to go to the hospital twice for it cuz the first time, they numbed it up really good then lanced and drained it, and sent me home. In and out just like that. (of course they cleaned and packed it with gauze and all that good fun stuff) The slit they cut was a good inch long and id say an inch or so deep. It was crazy. Well as it turned out, they hadn't gotten it all out. All that slicing and draining and cleaning and it still wasn't out. My entire lower leg at that point was super red and swollen and hurt. So i go back to the hospital and explain what happened and they look at it and were like. "yeah they shouldve admitted you yesterday, this is a serious case of MRSA." that being said i was admitted and had surgery on my leg for it and they got everything out that time. But has anyone else had the same reaction with a brown recluse?

these spiders are scavengers and their venom is meant to break down old crusty dead insects no to kill. That is why the venom dissolves flesh like it does. I was told it will even dissolve bone but I have not verified that. The are shy and the main reason they bite is because we use bug spray which does not kill them but gives them nerve damage and makes them aggressive and crazy. Insecticides do not kill these spiders most of the time. It does damage them and they wander around and bite even though it is not really their nature. It is very rare to get bitten by one who is not damage by bug spray.

So if you see one do not spray it. I cannot tell you to try to relocate it because it is dangerous and you have to do what you think is best. But if you kill it do not torture it. That is wrong no matter how you try to justify it. just kill it and be done with it.

On a final note, house spiders, wolf spiders and black widows are their major predators. They like to walk along the floorboard as they do not see very well and cobweb spiders feast on them. I never kill house spiders. i will relocate wolf spiders back outside when they get too big to live in the house. But for the most part I have lots of different spiders in my house. On the up side I have no roaches or other pest and I do not have to call an exterminator. :)

Just starting this series, I think I'll stick around for awhile.  Thanks for the tips, but I wish you'd gone into a little more detail about them.  It's pretty hard to identify what kind of spider it is by the macro-lens details when it's trucking across your pillow/chair/counter.  There is also at least one spider that's got something akin to the fiddle (barely different when seen thru a Wendy's cup with my bare eye...), so I eventually had to look up more differences.  One of the best was whether or not it has solid-colored legs.  It seems BRs always do, so even if it looks a little fiddle-y, if it's got a bunch of white leg stripes it's not one.  It could still be dangerous (mine was), but probably not as bad.
Also good to know (but not worth experimenting) is that not everyone is allergic to the BR's venom.  The site I read compared it to poison ivy; sometimes you get bit and don't even know it, just like any non-venomous spider.  Not sure if your 50% might be accounting for that, since I also learned they are non-aggressive (like you said) and typically don't bite unless they're in danger; this would include situations where it's getting squished by you when you climb into bed, put on shoes, etc.  Of course, they are not web builders so dark, warm areas are where they like to hang out.  My philosophy has always been, don't make your bed after getting up.  Air it out so the bed bugs and brown recluses don't find your residual body heat to be a fun hiding place.

@SmarterEveryDay   Ha! brown recluses are webless spiders!  ANND brown recluses have 6 eyes instead of 8 because they are hunters. They use their eyes to run around and get prey instead of having 8 eyes all different ways to see all angles around them to place web.  

Destin can you explore this?: I have put brown recluse bodies in high traffic areas because I live in NW Alabama and have a large recluse problem, Especially, since there is woods around my house.  Okay, so I put up dead brown recluse bodies where I catch them coming in the door of the house, and at the top of the stairs where they would come into my living area.  and I have noticed a decrease in activity.  My theory is that since they are intelligent hunters that they see this as a warning that they are not welcome, but they are welcome to run around outside the house and eat any insect they would like.  Is there anyway to explore this?

Also, have you ever heard of the spitting web spider?  you put this spider in a cup to establish a home and web and then take off the lid. It will stay in the cup, then emit a pheromone Esque smell that gets brown recluses to pursue it, then the spitting spider (which you place along walls and high traffic BR routes) will go into the spitting spiders web, be spat on with sticky web, will be subdue, then eaten, and thus brown recluse problem is all but solved.  You do live with another spider but they are cool and are spitting spiders which i assume because of their tobacco dipping habit.

Also!  This is very important!  I will directly quote Arlo from the Quaoar Power channel:  "Many insecticidal sprays do not kill the Brown Recluse, but they may cause nerve damage; maddening the spider and causing aggressive behavior."

I checked a few other university sources and, while there are some effective chemical treatments against them, not many of them are still available as over-the-counter pesticides.  A webpage from osu.edu stated the following:  "It would be prudent to enlist the services of a professional pest management company when dealing with an indoor infestation of the brown recluse spider."  Source:  http://ohioline.osu.edu/hyg-fact/2000/2061.html

That being said, it would definitely seem that fire may be a more effective extermination method for this particular species or arachnids. :P

Having the 6 eyes instead of 8 is characteristic of the family Sicariidae, not just of the brown recluse (Loxosceles reclusa).  The brown recluse looks nearly identical to another often encountered spider the Mediterranean recluse (Loxosceles rufescens).  Though we have not yet fully analyzed the venom of the MedRec we can assume (for safety sake) that it is probably similar. 

To finish up, random question to ya: How many deaths have been associated with spider bites in the last 5 years? 

According to the CDC, 0.

DYK:  spiders are blind.  All of those "eyes" they sport are only good for sensing light. 

DYK:  spiders kill the insects which plague humans?  Insects that ruin whole crops, spread diseases, and blight houses. 

DYK:  most reported spider bites are actually not spider bites?  Most of these "red bumps" are not bites of any kind.  Studies have been done to prove it.  People are so chicken shit about spiders, they construct imaginary "attacks" to explain itchy spots on their skin.

If you are the size of a giant compared to an animal, are you big and strong and powerful for igniting it while it's still alive?  Would it ahave killed you to just smoosh it first, then burn it?  For Christ's sake.  If Brwon REcluse spiders weren't meant to be, they wouldn't exist.  Are you God? I have to comment to this video to try to add to people's knowledge of these creatures. Fact #1 More people die from Brown Recluse bites than any other spider in the US. Fact #2 most folks don't understand the nature of "Hemotoxins" - The venom of the Brown Recluse acts like acid on animal (human) flesh and even more drastically on internal organ tissue. A victim bitten on the neck or near other major arteries can die in less than an hour if the toxins make their way to the heart, dissolving it as it beats. Case #1. My father was bitten on the top of his foot by one in the Caribbean, it took three days before he was able to get to a US hospital that recognized what it was. He didn't die because of poor circulation in his feet but his main artery had turned black half way up his leg. By the time the wound was finally irrigated and cleared of toxins, he had a hole in the top of his foot the size of a silver dollar that burrowed past the bones and tendons of his foot. It took several skin grafts and nearly six months to heal this wound. These are EXTREMELY dangerous spiders and very difficult to spot and we have every right to be cautious of them! They can kill your smaller pets even faster!

The spider would die before you could say fire.

As for the fire death. If you've ever been unlucky enough to have seen somebody burn to death, you would know that the death is anything but instant. It takes a good deal of time for life threatening symptoms like edema, hyperthermia, swelling of the airways, etc to take effect. It then takes more time for these symptoms to become severe enough that they eventually cause death. It's not a very nice way to go. The small size of the spider may cause this to happen faster, but it still takes time.

You're right, nothing is instant, physics doesn't allow it (except for quantum mechanics, but that's another story). Not even what we see/feel/touch. it takes time for our nerve cells to detect that change in stimulus and more time for it to transmit that signal to your brain, which takes time to process that signal. When you see something, it takes time for the light reflected/emitted from that object to reach your eyes, you are seeing it as it was a fraction of a fraction of a second earlier.

What kind of fire would not have killed the spider instantly, a piece of smoking paper?
"the point of time now present or present with reference to some action or event", nothing is ever one point in time, so according to that definition, nothing is instant.

No actually, instant has a set definition as follows:

an infinitesimal or very short space of time; a moment

or

the point of time now present or present with reference to some action or event. 

And seeing as the spider's death was not actually shown on the video, you can't say with any amount of accuracy how quickly it would have died.
instant is a relative term, according to you, nothing is instant. But compared to a human being burned to death, the spider's death was instant.
But burning to death ISN'T instant. Nor is anything heated up past its boiling point instantly, so no vaporization. Sorry.

They aren't on the East coast.The coast is not suitable for Recluse anywhere, and most of the far eastern states don't have them, but do have spider commonly mistaken for such.
That is stupid.Recluse are easy to identify by their eye arrangement, and most other brown spiders have clear differences from Recluse.
No, they don't exist in Florida.That's out of range and too close to the coast to support them.

No, you don't have Recluse in maine.I'm not sure what map you are speaking of, but Recluse spiders don't exist in Maine.There are many Maine spiders commonly mistaken for Recluse, such as Hacklemesh weavers, Cellar spiders, and Wolf spiders.The only dangerous spider there is the Northern Black widow.
That's a bit far-fetched.The Recluse spiders cannot survive in such a climate, and the odds of one getting transported are very low, even though if it did happen the spider would parish quickly.

Yes, you are.Iowa climate is not suitable for any kind of Recluse, but there are a lot of myths out there.Many spiders in your area can also be easily mistaken to be a Recluse by those who don't study spiders.
That's sickly.I highly doubt what you fried was any species of Recluse.

It's not for certain that Necrosis will occur.Necrosis is a fairly common effect of a Recluse bite, but they don't always cause Necrosis, sometimes they give dry bites and sometimes even the venom doesn't even have such an effect.Arachnologists estimate that 80% of Necrotic wounds diagnosed as Recluse bites are misdiagnosed.Even more evidence for this is that Necrotic wounds are repeatedly diagnosed as "Hobo spider" bites, even though those have been proven not responsible.

Recluse spiders are considered Dangerous, but they are almost never deadly.Google and whoever "environmentalgraffiti" is aren't proof.Arachnologist statements and studies are proof, most of the information on Google are pure myths.Find Richard Vetters statement on the toxicity of the Recluse spiders, it's quite eye opening.

They can tolerate colder temperatures and drier climates, so their range is larger than that of the brown recluse.

If you get bitten by one, kill the spider but do not discard the killed spider, keep it for precise identification. It is always good to know what you have been bitten by for sure before going through different treatment.

If you get bitten, rinse off the wound spot with cold water (cold water is very important because the most dangerous components of the spider's venom are the digestive enzymes and digestive enzymes become deactivated at low temperatures so it is very important to immediately rinse the bite mark with cold water) when you have rinsed the bite mark for 20-45 mins, apply dermal anti-biotic ONLY cream to prevent local infection and make ABSOLUTELY sure to see a doctor for further treatment.

This is one of the most dangerous spiders ever, the venom of the spider contains a series of very potent DIGESTIVE ENZYMES that literally digest and eat through the bite spot. If untreated the wound will expand and will get infected. Most of the untreated wounds usually lead to amputations on the limbs. The bite of this spider on Children under the age of 16 and on elderly has caused documented fatalities. If you see them kill them, don't be hesitant just kill them for good.

Most of what you hear about brown recluses and hobo spiders is hyperbole.  They are simply not in Alaska. Tests on the toxicity of Hobo spiders never produced necrosis, and confirmed bites never produced necrosis either. Hobo spiders are harmless, and can't be found in Alaska either. Alaska also has venomous bees.

"Only bite about 50% of the people"?  There was a famous case of a family of four in Kansas finding over 2,000 brown recluses in their home over 6 months with any bites.  This is typical. I've found about a dozen in my house, and no one in my family has ever been bitten.  I have friends that have them by the hundreds, and no bites.
No one has ever died from the bite of a brown recluse, so calling them "deadly" is not very accurate. The vast majority of brown recluse bite cases are hyperbole.

I did get smarter but in the way you think. I was always told the only venomous creature to worry about in Alaska was this spider. So when I saw the map I said bullshit. The Hobo spider looks similar to the Brown Recluse. The Hobo has 8 eyes, is generally hairy, and most have markings on their abdomen (the big fat tail end). The Recluse, like the vid mentions, has six eyes and has the upside down fiddle on the thorax (middle part between abdomen and head).

The amount of times that Brown Recluse bites occur isn't the issue. Rare or not, it only takes ONE instance for their to be serious harm. One should do their best to protect their family from all forms of harm, be they regular occurrences or seldom.

Brown recluses don't live in Utah. Next time you find one of those brown spiders, look at the eye pattern and compare it to the eye pattern in this video; brown recluses have a distinct and recognizable eye pattern.

Jeff Hanneman's liver failure (which killed him, not the necrosis) was not caused by a brown recluse bite.

It's possible that even the necrosis wasn't caused by a bite; plenty of people (And doctors) have misdiagnosed different kinds of skin lesions as brown recluse bites because it's one of the most famous causes of necrosis. Hanneman never saw the spider in question either.

Spider bites (as in actual spider bites, not "I was bitten when I was asleep even though there was no dead spider") are rare in North America. You're not going to get bitten most of the time.

I appreciate removing the spider, because it certainly is a risk for children in its vicinity. However, it's still a risk that gets far more attention from crazies than bathtubs, electrical outlets, food that's gone bad, cleaning fluids, stairs, and other things that kill far more kids per year. :-)

Brown recluse spiders breed in very large amounts; when you see a few, there will probably be many, many, many more. As said in the video, they don't bite much at all (There was a study in a house with literally thousands of recluses; not one bite for the family); the most common situations for spider bites are people inadvertently pressing into them. 

However, I certainly wouldn't want them anywhere near my child's bedroom; it'd be like having a big dog that your kid may inadvertently set off.

If you want to make somebody see reason, it's probably better to stay away from casting aspersions. In this case, the seeming cruelty of the act, accompanied by the fact that it was put on public display, may be the source of the confusion. Smashchamps77 probably just doesn't appreciate how dangerous these spiders can be, that Destin only posted the video as a service to the public, and  that he dispatched it in the least cruel way he could think of.

Anything with neurons and a brain can feel pain.

The easiest way to dispatch spiders is to freeze them, I've found.  Turn a can of duster upside down and start to barely spray.  Refrigerant will start to drip out of the tube.  Move the end of the tube to be over the spider while it's still dripping and it will be immediately subdued if you hit the body with a drop.  Let a few more drops fall to fully kill.  If it's moving, use the liquid spray instead of using drips.

Poisons are dangerous when ingested, venoms are dangerous when injected into the blood stream. From wiki: "Toxins are poisons produced by some biological function in nature, and venoms are usually defined as toxins that are injected by a bite or sting to cause their effect, while other poisons are generally defined as substances absorbed through epithelial linings such as the skin or gut." Nothing to do with how they're made.

Poison is a toxin that is man made while venom is created by nature with animals and plants that used for self defense and capturing prey. Toxin is usually referred to elements in there raw state i believe (e.g, sulfur is toxic).
What is the difference between poison and venom?

I agree that the spider's nervous system is relatively simple, when compared to that of a human, and I agree that it certainly did not feel the pain the same way a human would, if subject to a similar fate.
However, saying that it'd die painlessly in such extreme conditions is a strong claim that I do not think has equally strong evidence to support it.
You're right about it being an ethics issue, which is my concern. If the spider feels pain (even a rudimentary form of it), it's unethical.

The nervous system of spiders and insects is not complex enough to feel pain in the way that humans do. That doesn't necessarily mean that they do not deserve humane treatment, but that is an ethics issue. Strictly speaking, the spider would have died painlessly even if he'd have cut it in half and buried it alive in sand.

I live in N. FL and brown recluse/brown widow spiders pop up a lot in my area.  The problem with bringing them outside is that they reproduce.  Rapidly.  In a neighborhood where houses are close together, that can spell trouble.  I find brown widow eggs around my house all the time.  Even with consistent extermination.  I always worry about my dog going out the dog door because they like to attach eggs there.  And the brown widow eggs are easy to identify because they are spiky looking.

I have to politely disagree, onsaphi.  I squished a spider that was pregnant (didn't realize it was), and at least 100 babies scattered all over the place.  Freaked me out because I couldn't squish all of those quick enough. They were so small that they sunk into the carpet and didn't get crushed.  At least a third got away.  Burning a spider is quick and efficient, and no more or less curel than squishing.  They both kill quickly, but burning really does eliminate potential escape artists.

Insects lack the neurological structures that translate a negative stimulus into an emotional experience. Studies have shown pain-avoidance behavior is lacking in most species and its importance for is minimal at best. Most of what they do is by instinct alone. Ex. a locust will continue to feed up until death if it is caught and being eaten alive by a Mantid. The "ow that hurts" kind of pain is an emotional response to negative stimuli. I live in Australia and I get a lot of spiders during the summer months, but I usually just watch them scurry away.
